text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
HELSINGIN SANOMAT
- The next few years will witness worldwide concentration in the forestry industry as firms come under pressure to merge, says consultancy firm Jaakko Poyry.
- Finnish pianist Ralf Gothoni takes small-scale chamber music festival to Beijing with Finnish corporate sponsorship.
- Lesser white-fronted goose under threat of extinction in the Nordic region due to hunting, experts say. @
- Women's entrance into journalism has not reduced their negative portrayal in the media -- condescending attitude towards them has become subtle, says media consultant.
- Finnish high school students' performance in the International Baccaleauriat programme among best in world.
- Disney to begin operating its own recording company, Biena Vista, in Finland -- reducing Finnkino's share of corporation's wholesale distribution to a third of current level. @
KAUPPALEHTI
- Power producers assess potential environmental impact of several coal- and gas-fired power plants projected to be built along Finland's coast.

- German media giant Bertelsmann's withdrawal from German digital television market boosts Nokia's position in German market for TV set-top multimedia decoders, which Nokia has already sold to competing Kirch group.
Finland's 12 weakest department stores have combined losses of 150 million markka. @
- Consulting firm Propax Ltd founded to secure orders for Finnish companies from U.N. peacekeeping operations.
DEMARI
- Labour Minister Liisa Jaakonsaari says unemployment will not be halved by creating jobs with weaker social security.
- Unfinished project to cover the sunken ferry Estonia with a layer of gravel has so far cost 150 million markka, Swedish navigation authorities say. @
AAMULEHTI
- Tampere city orchestra gives concerts this week under the baton of 93-year-old St Petersburg conductor Ilya Musin.
- Sweden has sent back to Finland 10 Tamil refugees who were smuggled through Finnish territory three weeks ago.
TURUN SANOMAT
- Televised election panel discussion shows political parties, with sole exception of the Conservatives, ready to delay Finnish entry into EMU.
- Finland has offered to coordinate international military support to Estonia, Defence Minister Anneli Taina said. @
--Helsinki Newsroom +358-0-680 50 235
